title: How to send a password securely
excerpt: Stop sending credentials in chat apps. Use one-time secrets with expiry.

content.text: Sending passwords in chat apps is the fastest way to leak them. Screenshots, sync backups, message forwarding, and notifications all work against you.

content.title: Rule #1
content.text: If it can be copied and re-shared, assume it will be.
The real problem is workflow
Most leaks aren’t ‘hackers’. They’re ordinary habits. People copy secrets into places designed for conversation, not containment.

items: Search makes old secrets easy to find

content.text: Use a one-time secret link
Create a secret, set an expiry, and share the link. Once opened, it disappears. A leaked link after that becomes worthless.
Recommended settings

items: Use a passphrase for high-risk secrets
Never send passphrase in same channel as the link

content.text: Security that depends on people behaving perfectly is not security.
content.by: Everyone who learned the hard way

content.text: Passphrases: do it right
A passphrase is only useful if it’s shared separately. Link in Signal, passphrase via phone call, or link in email and passphrase in chat. Split the risk.

title: Stop pasting API keys into Slack
excerpt: Slack is great for coordination. It’s terrible for secrets. Here’s the fix.

content.text: Slack and Teams are built for communication and collaboration. They are not built for secret custody. The moment a key enters chat, you lose control of who can see it, where it’s stored, and how long it survives.
Why chat apps leak secrets by design

items: Retention: admins and exporters can access history
Bots and integrations: accidental exfiltration paths
Notifications: keys can show up on lock screens

content.title: Reality check
content.text: If your security relies on everyone deleting the message afterwards, you already lost.
The safe workflow

items: Put it into a one-time secret with expiry
Share passphrase via a different channel when needed
Confirm access and rotate again if unsure

content.text: How to handle incident response
If a key ever touched chat, treat it as compromised. Rotation is cheaper than a breach. Fix the workflow and move on.
The safest key is the one nobody can find.

content.title: Share keys safely
content.text: Use view-once links with expiry to avoid permanent chat leaks.

title: One-time links vs encrypted chat: what’s safer?
excerpt: Encryption helps, but it doesn’t solve persistence and workflow mistakes.

content.text: People love saying “just use encrypted chat”. Encryption is great, but it only protects data in transit. Most leaks happen after delivery: screenshots, forwarding, backups, exports, and device compromises.
What encrypted chat does well
What encrypted chat does NOT fix

items: Admins can export in many org tools

content.text: Where one-time links shine
One-time secrets reduce the blast radius of human mistakes. Even if someone forwards the link, the secret has already self-destructed after access or expiry.

content.title: Best practice
content.text: Use encrypted chat for coordination. Use one-time secrets for actual secrets.

content.title: Use the right tool
content.text: Send secrets as secrets, not as messages.

title: Secure sharing for teams without slowing down
excerpt: The best security workflow is the one people will actually follow.

content.text: Teams don’t fail security because they’re evil. Teams fail security because they’re busy. Your job is to create a workflow that is faster than bad habits.
Make the secure path the default path

items: Audit: treat chat leaks as incidents

content.text: Stop the “temporary” message myth
A “temporary” secret shared in chat is rarely temporary. People scroll. People search. People export. The secret lasts as long as your retention policy.
A simple policy that works

items: Use one-time secrets for any token or password
Split link and passphrase when in doubt

content.text: Security is just good habits with paperwork.

title: Password reset links are secrets too
excerpt: Reset links can be used to take over accounts. Treat them like passwords.

content.text: A password reset link is basically a temporary master key. If someone else gets it before the user does, they can hijack the account.
Common ways reset links leak
Safe support workflow

items: Ask user to initiate reset themselves when possible
If you must send a reset link, send it via one-time secret
Verify identity before any reset steps

content.title: Support rule
content.text: Never ask users to send passwords or tokens. Ever.

title: What expiry time should you use for secrets?
excerpt: Long enough to be usable, short enough to limit damage.

content.text: Expiry is your damage control. Too short and people hate you. Too long and secrets linger like bad decisions.
A practical expiry guide

items: Medium risk (API key for dev): 15–60 minutes

content.text: If you’re unsure
Default to 60 minutes with view-once. It’s enough for humans to respond and short enough to limit re-sharing risk.

content.title: Pro tip
content.text: View-once reduces risk more than long expiries ever will.

content.title: Set expiry automatically
content.text: Create secrets with sensible defaults, fast.

title: Why view-once matters more than encryption
excerpt: Encryption protects delivery. View-once controls what happens after delivery.

content.text: Encryption is necessary. It is not sufficient. Most leaks happen after the recipient receives the data.
View-once reduces blast radius
If a message can be replayed, it can be forwarded and searched forever. View-once changes the economics of mistakes: forwarded links become useless after first access.
When view-once is essential

content.title: Simple rule
content.text: If it would hurt to leak tomorrow, it shouldn’t still exist tomorrow.

content.title: Use view-once by default

title: Retention policies keep secrets alive forever
excerpt: Even if you delete messages, retention and exports can keep secrets around.

content.text: Organizations retain chat logs, email, and tickets for legal and compliance reasons. That means secrets pasted into those systems can persist for years.
Why this matters
The fix
Don’t fight retention. Avoid placing secrets in systems that retain. Use view-once links instead.

content.title: Simple policy
content.text: Secrets never go into retained systems.

content.title: Avoid retention leaks
content.text: Share secrets outside long-retention channels.

title: Passphrase sharing: the simplest rule that actually works
excerpt: Split the secret and the passphrase. One channel each. Stop overthinking it.

content.text: Adding a passphrase is great. Sending it in the same chat as the secret link is pointless. You just wrapped a gift and taped the key to the box.
The rule

content.title: Rule
content.text: Link and passphrase never travel together.
Practical pairings

items: Link in chat, passphrase by phone
Link in email, passphrase in chat
Link in ticket, passphrase in secure message

content.text: When to use passphrases
Use them for high-impact secrets: prod tokens, recovery codes, admin access. Don’t add friction to low risk data unless you enjoy people bypassing your process.

content.title: Share with a passphrase
content.text: Add a passphrase when it matters and share it separately.
